title: Discussion Thread Design: Reddit-Inspired Visual Tree Structure & Optimized Comment Layout
description:
Redesign the discussion thread comment display to match Reddit's proven design patterns, improving visual hierarchy, space efficiency, and conversation flow. Implement a tree-like comment structure with visual connectors and optimize redundant user information display.

CURRENT STATE:
The discussion thread pages (src/app/discussion/thread/[id]/page.tsx) display comments with several UX issues:

1. REDUNDANT USER INFO (ReplyCard.tsx:86-96)
   - User's displayName shown in comment header (line 88)
   - User's title shown in comment header (line 91)
   - Both pieces of info repeat for every single comment/reply
   - Takes up significant vertical space with repeated information
   - No visual parent-to-child reply indication

2. FLAT VISUAL STRUCTURE (ReplyList.tsx:18-96)
   - Nested replies only use margin-left (ml-11 in Tailwind)
   - No visual connector lines between parent and child comments
   - No thread lines showing relationship hierarchy
   - Only 2 levels of nesting supported (parent + direct replies)
   - Difficult to follow multi-level conversations

3. SPACE INEFFICIENCY
   - Each reply header: user name + title + timestamp = multiple lines
   - No compact author display option
   - Vertical spacing between replies feels generous (space-y-6, space-y-4)

REDDIT'S PROVEN APPROACH:
Reddit uses a sophisticated comment thread design:

- HIERARCHICAL INDENTATION: Left-side visual borders at 4-12px width serve as navigation
- CLICKABLE TREE LINES: Each level of nesting has its own left border
- COMPACT AUTHOR INFO: Username + badge/title shown once, not repeated
- TREE STRUCTURE: Visual path showing how conversation branches
- DEPTH INDICATION: Users can count vertical lines to understand nesting level
- COLLAPSIBLE THREADS: Comments can be collapsed to hide nested replies

SOLUTION REQUIREMENTS:

1. IMPLEMENT REDDIT-STYLE TREE VISUALIZATION
   [ ] Left-side colored borders for each nesting level
   [ ] Vertical lines connecting parent comments to child replies
   [ ] Horizontal connector at start of reply showing it's a child
   [ ] Visual color coding for different nesting depths
   [ ] Smooth transition lines (no jagged connections)
   [ ] Responsive spacing that works on mobile

2. OPTIMIZE USER INFO DISPLAY
   [ ] Show author info only once per comment thread
   [ ] Move redundant metadata (title) to optional badge/label
   [ ] Consider displaying author info above thread instead of in comment
   [ ] Keep timestamp visible but compact (relative time: '2h ago')
   [ ] Show author's badge/role efficiently without waste

3. IMPROVE SPACE EFFICIENCY
   [ ] Reduce vertical spacing between comments (conditional on nesting level)
   [ ] Use consistent grid-based spacing
   [ ] Compact reply header design
   [ ] Optimize avatar + text layout
   [ ] Better use of horizontal space

4. ENHANCE VISUAL HIERARCHY
   [ ] Distinct visual treatment for top-level vs nested comments
   [ ] Color-code nesting levels or use opacity gradients
   [ ] Clear visual distinction between comment and its replies
   [ ] Better affordances for reply interaction
   [ ] Collapsible comment threads (show 'n replies' button)

5. IMPLEMENT DEEPER NESTING
   [ ] Support unlimited nesting depth (or practical limit like 5-7 levels)
   [ ] Prevent right-side overflow on very deep threads
   [ ] Add 'continue reading thread' for very deep nesting
   [ ] Maintain readability at all nesting levels

TECHNICAL IMPLEMENTATION:

Files to Modify:
- src/components/discussions/ReplyCard.tsx - Individual comment component
- src/components/discussions/ReplyList.tsx - Comment list and grouping logic
- src/app/globals.css - Add CSS for tree visualization and connectors

Design Patterns to Implement:
1. CSS Approach: Use left-border with background-image for vertical lines
2. Pseudo-elements: ::before and ::after for connector lines
3. Recursive Component Structure: Support infinite nesting
4. Optional Collapsing: Add collapse/expand functionality

CSS Techniques (based on CSS-Tricks styling):
- Position absolute left borders with correct height calculation
- Use border-left for main thread line
- Use border-left with gradient for color transitions
- Clickable areas (12px) wider than visible border (4px)
- Fixed header height for border calculation

Components to Refactor:
1. ReplyCard
   - Separate header display logic
   - Add visual tree connector elements
   - Implement collapse state
   - Optimize metadata layout

2. ReplyList
   - Recursively build tree structure
   - Group replies at multiple levels
   - Add visual styling for tree connections
   - Implement collapse/expand groups

DESIGN SPECIFICATIONS:

Color Scheme for Nesting Levels:
- Level 0 (top): Primary color (sage/green)
- Level 1: Secondary color (terracotta/orange)
- Level 2: Tertiary color (muted sage)
- Level 3+: Grayscale gradient

Spacing:
- Top-level comment: Space-y-6 (existing)
- First-level nested: Space-y-3
- Deeper nested: Space-y-2
- No left margin, use visual border instead

Typography:
- Author name: Keep bold
- Title/badge: Make optional, subtle styling
- Timestamp: Keep small and secondary
- Hide title on very deep nesting if space is tight

ACCEPTANCE CRITERIA:
- [ ] Visual tree lines connect parent and child comments
- [ ] Left-side borders show nesting depth
- [ ] User info displayed efficiently without redundancy
- [ ] Supports minimum 3+ levels of nesting (like Reddit)
- [ ] Collapse/expand functionality for nested threads
- [ ] Responsive design works on mobile (375px+)
- [ ] Performance: No lag with 100+ comments
- [ ] Accessibility: Tree structure clear via semantic HTML
- [ ] Tested with real comment threads (deep nested conversations)

INSPIRATION SOURCES:
- Reddit comment threads: https://reddit.com/r/announcements/
- CSS-Tricks styling guide: https://css-tricks.com/styling-comment-threads/
- Medium.com nested comments UI

RELATED ISSUES:
- Part of larger discussion UX improvements
- Complements existing thread voting and reply functionality
- Sets stage for advanced comment features (threading, mentions, etc.)
notes: Research completed on Reddit's design approach and CSS tree visualization techniques. Ready for design mockup and implementation.

title: Month Calendar: Date positioning and event indicator redesign
description:
# Month Calendar - Date Cell Design Improvements

## Problem Statement

The month calendar's day cells have two usability issues that reduce visual hierarchy and make event scanning difficult:

1. **Date Number Positioning**: The day number is centered both vertically and horizontally in the cell. This is inconsistent with Google Calendar's design pattern where the date is positioned at the top of the cell, making it easier to scan down a column of dates.

2. **Event Indicators Too Small**: The colored dots representing events are only 6-7px diameter. These are a critical visual element for quickly identifying days with events, but are currently too small to create visual impact.

## Current Implementation

**Files involved:**
- `src/components/calendar/DateCell.tsx` - Day cell component (lines 65-87 contain date number and dots)
- `src/app/globals.css` - Styling at lines 1816-1920

**Current CSS:**
- `.date-cell-compact` uses `align-items: center` and `justify-content: center`
- `.item-dot` is 6px (mobile) / 7px (desktop)

## Requirements (80% - Clear Specifications)

### 1. Date Number Positioning
- Date number MUST be positioned at the **top-center** of the cell (not centered vertically)
- This aligns with Google Calendar's month view pattern
- Maintains readability when scanning down calendar columns

### 2. Event Indicators Enhancement
- Event indicators MUST be visually prominent (at least 3x larger than current 6-7px)
- Consider alternatives to dots: small colored bars/blocks (like Google Calendar), or larger circular indicators
- Indicators MUST remain clearly associated with their date cell
- Support for multiple event types via different colors (existing functionality)

### 3. Responsive Behavior
- Changes must work across mobile (375px+), tablet, and desktop viewports
- Ensure sufficient touch targets for mobile interaction

### 4. Accessibility
- Maintain existing ARIA labels and keyboard navigation
- Ensure sufficient color contrast for event indicators

## Solution Space (20% - Agent Creative Freedom)

The agent has flexibility to determine:
- Exact pixel sizing for event indicators (recommend 10-14px minimum for visual impact)
- Shape: dots, rounded rectangles/bars, or other creative solutions
- Positioning of indicators relative to date number (below, or spanning the cell)
- Whether to use animation or hover effects for additional prominence
- Use of the existing color system (terracotta, sage, forest) or expanded palette

## Design References

- Google Calendar month view: Date number at top, event bars/blocks below
- Modern Material 3 Expressive redesign uses rounded cell corners with color backgrounds
- Event indicators should be one of the most prominent elements in the calendar

## Acceptance Criteria

1. Date number appears at top-center of cell, not centered
2. Event indicators are minimum 10px in size (or equivalent visual weight)
3. Calendar remains usable on mobile (375px width)
4. All existing calendar functionality preserved (date selection, navigation)
5. Tests pass (if applicable)

title: Discussion Page: Equal height sidebar and content panel + bg-sage-light
description:
# Discussion Page - Equal Height Layout & Background Color

## Problem Statement

Two design issues on the discussion landing page:

1. **Unequal Height Between Sidebar and Content Panel**
   - The category tabs (left sidebar) and discussions-content-panel (right) have mismatched heights
   - When there are few threads, the content panel is shorter than the category tabs
   - This creates visual imbalance - the category tabs appear "taller" than the content
   - Both sections should stretch to match the tallest element (standard flexbox equal-height columns pattern)

2. **White Background Creates Visual Clutter**
   - The `discussions-content-panel` uses `background: white`
   - The site has many white background elements, causing visual fatigue
   - Should use `bg-sage-light` for better visual hierarchy and variety

## Current Implementation

### Files Involved
- `src/app/globals.css` - Lines 5935-6097

### Current CSS
```css
/* Layout container (line 5935) */
.discussions-sidebar-layout {
  display: flex;
  gap: 0;
  min-height: 600px;
}

/* Content panel (line 6087) */
.discussions-content-panel {
  flex: 1;
  background: white;  /* <-- ISSUE: should be sage-light */
  border: 1px solid rgba(168, 181, 160, 0.2);
  border-radius: 0 16px 16px 16px;
  padding: var(--space-lg);
  min-width: 0;
  /* ... */
}
```

### Missing CSS
- `.discussions-sidebar-layout` lacks `align-items: stretch` (the default, but should be explicit)
- `.discussions-content-wrapper` may need adjustment to allow stretching

## Requirements (80% - Clear Specifications)

### 1. Equal Height Layout
- The category tabs sidebar and content panel MUST be equal height
- Both elements should stretch to match the tallest element
- Use CSS flexbox `align-items: stretch` on the parent container
- If content is shorter than sidebar, content panel still matches sidebar height
- If content is taller than sidebar, sidebar matches content height

### 2. Background Color Change
- `discussions-content-panel` MUST use `bg-sage-light` instead of `white`
- This applies to the rounded panel on the right side
- Ensure text remains readable against sage-light background
- Check contrast ratios for accessibility

### 3. Responsive Behavior
- On mobile (< 1024px), layout stacks vertically - this behavior should remain
- The equal-height fix applies primarily to desktop layout

### 4. Visual Integrity
- The border and shadow treatments should work well with sage-light
- May need subtle border color adjustment for sage-light background

## Solution Space (20% - Agent Creative Freedom)

The agent can determine:
- Exact CSS approach for equal-height (align-items: stretch vs other methods)
- Whether to add `align-items: stretch` explicitly to `.discussions-sidebar-layout` or `.discussions-content-wrapper`
- Any border/shadow adjustments needed for sage-light background
- Whether `--sage-light` CSS variable exists or needs to be created

## Acceptance Criteria

1. Category tabs and content panel are always equal height on desktop
2. Content panel uses `bg-sage-light` (or equivalent variable)
3. Mobile layout (stacked) continues to work correctly
4. Text remains readable with new background
5. Visual design remains polished with shadows/borders
6. No regression in existing functionality

title: Management Request Portal: Mobile Dropdown Menu Cut-off Bug
description:
The report type dropdown menu on the mobile Management Request Portal (/management-request/) displays menu options that are cut off or hidden, preventing users from selecting certain report types.

PROBLEM:
When users open the category dropdown menu on mobile devices, not all report type options are visible. Options below the fold are either cut off or completely hidden. The dropdown menu has no scrolling capability, making it impossible to access all available report types.

AFFECTED DEVICES:
- Mobile: 375px, 414px, 540px width viewports
- Landscape mobile orientations
- Dropdown positioned near bottom of screen
- Any mobile where dropdown extends beyond viewport

ROOT CAUSE:
The .category-dropdown-menu CSS (globals.css:5364-5376) lacks:

1. MAX-HEIGHT: No max-height defined
   - Menu expands unconstrained
   - Items extend beyond viewport
   - No height limit on mobile

2. SCROLL CAPABILITY: overflow: hidden
   - Should be: overflow-y: auto
   - Prevents scrolling through options
   - Hides all options below fold

CRITICAL CSS ISSUES:

File: src/app/globals.css, lines 5364-5376

.category-dropdown-menu {
  position: absolute;
  top: 100%;
  left: 0;
  right: 0;
  margin-top: 4px;
  background: white;
  border: 1px solid var(--sage);
  border-radius: 12px;
  box-shadow: 0 8px 24px rgba(26, 34, 24, 0.12);
  overflow: hidden;  /* WRONG: Should be overflow-y: auto */
  list-style: none;
  /* MISSING: max-height property */
}

SOLUTION REQUIRED:

1. Add max-height: 240px (or 50vh on mobile)
2. Change overflow: hidden to overflow-y: auto
3. Add overflow-x: hidden to prevent horizontal scroll
4. Improve z-index (currently 50, should be 1000+)
5. Add mobile media query adjustments

FILES TO MODIFY:
- src/app/globals.css (PRIMARY): lines 5326-5403
- src/components/management-request/CategoryDropdown.tsx (OPTIONAL)

TESTING:
- Mobile 375px: All options visible and scrollable
- Mobile landscape: No cutoff
- Tablet/Desktop: No regression
- Keyboard navigation (arrow keys, Escape)
- Touch scroll on mobile: Smooth
- WCAG accessibility: >= 44px touch targets

ACCEPTANCE CRITERIA:
- All report type options visible on mobile dropdown
- Dropdown scrolls when exceeding available height
- No menu options cut off at any viewport width
- Dropdown stays within viewport bounds
- Touch and keyboard navigation functional
- No visual regression on desktop
- WCAG 2.1 compliant

IMPACT:
- Severity: High (blocks core form functionality)
- Scope: Mobile users only (desktop uses tabs)
- Effort: Low (CSS fix, 30-60 minutes)
- Risk: Very low (isolated CSS change)

title: Calendar Layout: Separate Year Overview Nav from Month Calendar Container
description:
The calendar page year overview navigation (mini month pages) shares the same constrained container with the month calendar. This causes the year overview nav to get cut off or hidden depending on screen resolution and viewport size.

PROBLEM:
- Both MonthCalendar and MonthNavigation are nested in .calendar-grid-column
- Container has max-height constraints with overflow: hidden
- When content grows, year overview nav becomes invisible
- Users cannot access month navigation on smaller resolutions

AFFECTED SCENARIOS:
- Mobile devices (375px-540px width)
- Tablet intermediate sizes (600px-900px)
- Desktop with reduced window height
- Content-heavy calendars with many event indicators

SOLUTION:
Create two distinct sections within calendar-grid-column:
1. Month Calendar Section (65-75% height, scrollable)
2. Year Overview Section (25-35% height, always visible)

FILES INVOLVED:
- src/components/calendar/CalendarViewContainer.tsx
- src/components/calendar/MonthCalendar.tsx
- src/components/calendar/MonthNavigation.tsx
- src/app/globals.css

DOCUMENTATION:
- docs/calendar-layout-investigation/ISSUE-DEFINITION.md
- docs/calendar-layout-investigation/LAYOUT-ANALYSIS.md

ACCEPTANCE CRITERIA:
- Year overview nav never cut off at any viewport width
- Distinct visual separation between sections
- Smooth responsive transitions at breakpoints
- Full visibility on mobile (375px+), tablet, and desktop

title: Mobile Hamburger Menu: Full redesign for spacing, sizing, and accessibility
description:
# Mobile Hamburger Menu Redesign

## Problem Statement

The mobile hamburger menu needs a complete redesign to improve:
1. **Spacing** - Links feel cramped and lack breathing room
2. **Logo/Title** - Needs better visual hierarchy and sizing
3. **Button sizing** - Touch targets and interactive elements need improvement
4. **Overall accessibility** - Ensure WCAG compliance and excellent user experience

The desktop navigation should remain completely unchanged - this is mobile-only work.

## Current Implementation

### Files Involved
- `src/components/layout/Header.tsx` - Main header with mobile menu dialog (lines 54-136)
- `src/app/globals.css` - Mobile navigation styling (lines 4990-5090+)
- `src/lib/constants.ts` - Navigation items (lines 10-20)

### Current Structure
The mobile menu uses Headless UI Dialog with:
- Slide-in from right animation
- Dark green background (`bg-forest/[0.98]`)
- Logo at top (lines 83-88)
- Main navigation items (lines 91-102)
- "More" section with icons (lines 105-122)
- Login button at bottom (lines 125-130)

### Current CSS Issues
- Navigation links: `px-4 py-3` (minimal padding)
- "More" section items: same padding
- Logo: `text-2xl` for "CORONATION", `text-[1.15em]` for "GARDENS"
- Touch targets may be below recommended 44px minimum
- Overall visual density is too high

### Navigation Items
**Main Navigation (4 items):**
- Discussion
- Report Issue
- Calendar
- Blog

**More Section (2 items):**
- About (with users icon)
- Map (with map icon)

**Primary Action:**
- Resident Login button

## Requirements (80% - Clear Specifications)

### 1. Logo/Title Redesign
- Logo MUST remain in the menu (top position, visible when open)
- Font sizing should create clear visual hierarchy
- Consider adding tagline "Residents Society" or similar
- Ensure logo is prominent but doesn't dominate the menu

### 2. Navigation Link Spacing
- Each link MUST have generous padding (recommend minimum `px-6 py-4` or equivalent)
- Clear visual separation between links
- Maintain or improve readability of link text

### 3. Button Sizing
- All interactive elements MUST meet 44x44px minimum touch target (WCAG guideline)
- Login button should be prominent and easily tappable
- Consider visual weight - buttons should feel substantial

### 4. Section Organization
- Maintain current structure (Main nav, More, Login)
- Add clear visual separation between sections
- Consider adding section headers or dividers

### 5. Accessibility
- Maintain existing ARIA attributes (already properly implemented)
- Ensure keyboard navigation works
- Maintain focus trap (already implemented via Headless UI)
- Color contrast must meet WCAG AA (4.5:1 for text)

### 6. Desktop Unchanged
- ALL changes MUST be scoped to mobile only (< md breakpoint)
- Desktop navigation must look and function exactly as before

## Solution Space (20% - Agent Creative Freedom)

The agent can determine:
- Exact pixel/spacing values for padding and margins
- Font sizes for logo and navigation (within accessible ranges)
- Visual treatment of section dividers
- Icon sizing in the "More" section
- Animation timing adjustments (if any)
- Color treatments for hover/active states

## Design Best Practices (References)

- Mobile touch targets: minimum 44x44px (WCAG)
- Thumb zone navigation patterns
- Generous whitespace improves comprehension by ~20%
- Clear visual hierarchy guides user attention
- Consistent spacing (multiples of 4px or 8px)

## Current Test Coverage

Tests exist in `tests/e2e/mobile/navigation.spec.ts`:
- Hamburger menu open/close functionality
- Backdrop click closes menu
- Animation smoothness
- Touch target adequacy
- ARIA attributes
- Focus trap

## Acceptance Criteria

1. Mobile menu has generous, elegant spacing throughout
2. Logo/title is visually prominent with clear hierarchy
3. All touch targets are minimum 44px
4. Sections (nav, more, login) are clearly separated
5. Desktop navigation unchanged - test on viewport 1024px+
6. All existing e2e tests continue to pass
7. Accessibility: color contrast meets WCAG AA
8. Smooth animations maintained
close_reason: Closed
